reality.title: Reality Check
reality.realisticDescription: Typical influences from ground, buildings, and vegetation

dipole.low: At low height, the dipole radiates steeply upward – ideal for NVIS contacts up to about 500 km.
dipole.medium: At medium height, a balanced radiation pattern develops for medium distances.
dipole.high: Mounted high, the radiation angle becomes flatter – better for DX contacts.

vertical.low: The vertical antenna radiates at a low angle by default, ideal for DX.
vertical.medium: Ground quality strongly affects efficiency – radials improve radiation.
vertical.high: More height above ground can be counterproductive for vertical antennas.

invertedV.low: The Inverted-V is a compromise between dipole and vertical with more omnidirectional radiation.
invertedV.medium: The opening angle of the legs significantly affects the radiation pattern.
invertedV.high: Mounted higher, the pattern approaches that of a horizontal dipole.

tips.realistic: In practice, ground, buildings, and trees affect the radiation pattern. This shows typical distortions.
